title: Soroban Abacus 101: Parts, Beads, and How It All Works
description: The soroban looks simple – just beads on rods. But there's elegant design behind every part. Here's everything parents need to know.
imageAlt: Diagram of soroban abacus parts and structure

content.intro: Before your child starts learning soroban, it helps to understand the tool itself. The Japanese soroban has been refined over centuries for speed and efficiency. Here's a breakdown of every part.

items: **Frame:** The outer border that holds everything together
**Rods (columns):** Vertical bars where beads slide up and down
**Beam (reckoning bar):** The horizontal divider in the middle
**Upper beads (heaven beads):** One bead above the beam, worth 5
**Lower beads (earth beads):** Four beads below the beam, worth 1 each

sections.text: Each rod represents one place value (ones, tens, hundreds, etc.):

items: **Upper bead = 5:** When pushed down to touch the beam
**Lower beads = 1 each:** When pushed up to touch the beam
**1 + 4 beads:** Any digit 0-9 with minimal bead movement
**Beam reference:** Clear "zero" state, beads away from beam
**Column layout:** Perfect for place value understanding

sections.text: The Chinese abacus has 2 upper beads and 5 lower beads. The Japanese soroban is more streamlined with 1 upper and 4 lower – optimized for speed.
If you're buying a physical soroban:

items: **13 rods:** Good for beginners, handles up to 9,999,999,999,999
**21+ rods:** For advanced users doing very large calculations

sections.text: Many parents ask if they need a physical soroban. Here's the truth:

items: **Physical:** Great for beginners, tactile feedback helps
**Virtual (app):** Perfect for practice, tracks progress, always available
**Both:** Many families start physical, then transition to app for daily practice

sections.text: You don't NEED to buy a physical soroban. Apps simulate it accurately. But having one for early learning can help – it's more tangible for young kids.

faq.question: Do I need to buy an expensive soroban?
faq.answer: No. A basic $10-15 plastic soroban works fine for learning. Premium wooden ones ($30-50) feel nicer but won't help your child learn faster.

faq.question: What's the dot on some rods for?
faq.answer: The unit rod marker – usually a dot on every third rod from the right. It helps locate the ones place quickly in large numbers.

faq.question: Why are some beads different colors?
faq.answer: Learning sorobans often use colors to help beginners. Traditional sorobans are one color. Either works for learning.
